repnme.cdata!:
Samoa - Infrastructure Asset Management
            Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a highly satisfactory
            project outcome, with a likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impacts. Lessons are as follows.
            The project design concept of combining related sub-sectors
            in a broader sector project worked satisfactorily, in spite
            of the involvement of five agencies. Keys to success
            include: an effective multi-agency steering committee,
            empowered to make project cost and coordination decisions,
            allowing a balanced coordination between implementing
            agencies, with the provision that agency representatives
            were empowered; a Project Management Unit, supplemented by
            specific project support in each implementing agency, which
            proved critically important in this multi-agency project,
            also effective in building capacity due to the line
            reporting and accountability of each agency for authorizing
            project expenditures; intensive monitoring and supervision
            with a good skill mix, from both the Bank and Government;
            and, well-defined indicators relevant to each agency, and to
            the project. In addition, the two-phase Adaptable Program
            Lending (APL) structure worked well from the Project
            perspective, particularly with respect to the public sector
            reform activities, the phasing was helpful because of two
            agencies, whish despite of differing pace and targets from
            that expected at appraisal, both in the end exceeded
            targets. The public works experience shows that sector
            reform can be introduced smoothly when the timing is well
            chosen - in this case, alignment of a national reform
            agenda, sector political will, committed executive leader,
            comprehensive consultations, and a sound, well-designed
            plan. Notwithstanding, the introduction of hazard risk
            management into public sector management needs a number of
            elements to be successful, and, the preparation of fiduciary
            arrangements such as procurement, and financial management
            needs to cover the whole transaction cycle in order to
            streamline the process.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Infrastructure Asset Management
            Project seeks to achieve an objective so that transport and
            coastal infrastructure assets are economically,
            environmentally, and socially sustainable and managed by an
            effective partnership of all stakeholders. There are five
            project components. 1) International airport infrastructure
            will increase the capacity for safe handling of
            international air traffic and improve Samoa Airport
            Authority's financial viability. It will support
            rehabilitation and extension of runway, improvement of
            terminal building and control tower facilities, acquisition
            of fire emergency vehicles, and engineering and architecture
            services for design and construction supervision. 2) Road
            system infrastructure will improve reliability and safety of
            road system assets. 3) Coastal infrastructure will initiate
            environmentally and socially sustainable management of
            coastal infrastructure. 4) Institutional development will
            change management of infrastructure to be service-oriented,
            involving public, private and community stakeholders. 5)
            Project management will handle project preparation and
            establish a project management unit.

repnme.cdata!:
Samoa - Infrastructure Asset Management
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Infrastructure Asset Management
            Project aims to improve air, road, and coastal transport
            infrastructure and to support public sector reform and
            increased private sector participation in the provision of
            infrastructure. The purpose of this environmental analysis
            is to identify and assess the environmental issues
            associated with the project and evaluate the need for
            further reviews. The airport improvement component may cause
            spillages from resurfacing materials resulting in pollution
            of groundwater and the lagoon ecosystem, which will be
            mitigated by adhering to proper procedures. Road subsector
            work may bring about dust and/or mud problems during
            construction. To mitigate such impact, codes of
            environmental practice will be observed. Under the coastal
            infrastructure component, groundwater flows to the coast may
            be inhibited, access to the coast may be curtailed, and
            lagoon ecosystem may be affected. Mitigation measures
            include designing coastal protection methods in consultation
            with the village concerned.
